use floats instead of decimals for the Style data

decimals led to problems with MySQL and since we deal with floats on the Lua
side, it makes sense to use floats on the DB side, too.
This shouldn't be a problem, because we don't do arithmetics with this values.

[#15 state:resolved]

remove major performance bottleneck in image map generation

The major problem was that C objects cannot be marshalled by DRb (obviously).
Therefore, when image_info.each_hotspot was called each request would be
handed over to the gt_server which returned the coordinates of a hotspot and a
proxy for the corresponding feature. Each call on the feature (like
feature.get_score) would produce another DRb call. All this DRb calls where
quite time consuming.

Solution: The ImageInfo class of gtruby was extended with a get_hotspots()
methods which collects all the necessary information at once.
With this method a single DRb call sends everything at once (it can be
marshalled now).
Because this method is somewhat special and is probably only useful in the
context of GenomeViewer, I put it in the gt_server himself (Ruby's open
classes made this possible).

Some ideas for further performance improvements:
- use a singe array/hash for a hotspot instead of an array with an embedded hash
- reduce the amount of displayed information
- inline some methods which build the image map
- use arrays to build string before concatenating them:

  s = []
  s << "multiple times"
  s.join

  instead of

  s = ""
  s << "multiple times"
  s

But only profiling can tell if this ideas work and are worth the effort.

TestHelper: created method "user_setup"

 As the storage is not only DB-based, i.e. annotations are saved as files,
 it is difficult to make use only of fixtures. This helper method uploads
 an annotation for an user, so that you have:

 - @_u => an user, with one annotation
 - @_a => annotation (of @_u)
 - @_sr => sequence region (of @_a)
 - @_ft => feature type (of @_a)
 - @_c => configuration (of @_u)
 - @_f => format (of @_f)

GTServer (Output): some more log information
Routes: image/:uuid

(MIGRATION): created table to log UUIDs

When a page containing an image (Viewer#index) is loaded,
an UUID is created. The image is generated on the GTServer
using the necessary parameters and the UUID as identifier.
The image is then loaded using as URL "image/#{uuid}".
As the GTServer is restarted each time the memory is full,
there is a concrete possibility that between the time the
image is generated and requested, the server is restarted.
If this happens then the #image method will use the log
to reconstruct the parameters and repeat the generation
request before the image is sent to the browser.

GTRubyConfigurator: improved

unit tests are now provided, actually testing some Format
and FeatureType objects, where the module is used, but focusing
more on the functionality included by the module

the unit tests of FeatureType and Format were updated too

attribute instance methods:
the normal get/set methods are now not overridden, that means they act
only locally, in the instance and not in the gt server;
a sync_<attr>=(value) method is provided for this purpose instead;
a remote_<attr>=(value) method is used for setting only the remote value,
i.e. in the gt server without setting the local instance value
a <attr>_sync? boolean method says if they are synchronized;
upload_<attr> and download_<attr> synchronize the value overwriting the
remote version (upload) or local (download)

section instance methods:
upload, download, sync? have the same meaning as for the single attributes;
upload and download accept exceptions (i.e. attributes that should not
be synchronized) in the form download_except(*attributes);
local, remote, default return an hash with values (from the instance, from
the gt server config object, from the gt server default config object)
not_sync returns information about not synchronized attributes

class methods:
default_new returns a new instance with default values

nomenclature changes:
"set_floats" is more correctly called "set_decimals", which is their
name in the database (they are casted by rails to BigDecimal)
"set_style" was changed to "set_styles", to distinguish the attribute
(style) from the collective type name (styles)
Annotation: updated FeatureType.default_new method call
Configuration: expanded unit tests
Configuration: corrected method that makes sure there is a format

Configuration: added correct support for GT::Config caching

when the object does not come from the cache, settings of all
sections are uploaded

gt method has now two facultative parameters, a section name and
attribute name: the corresponding section does not upload the
corresponding attribute; this is used by GTRubyConfiguration to
avoid circular method calls
FeatureType/Format: now using .default_new defined in GTRubyConfigurator

GTRubyConfigurator: expanded "default" functionality

- every attribute had already an #default_<attr> method to
  get the value from configuration.default (which references
  the default GT::Config object)

- now the instance has also a #default method which returns
  all returns in form of an hash :attribute => value

- the .default_new class method is defined which returns an instance
  with all values set to the default;

  this may require (currently in FeatureType) attributes (ftypes: name)
  to be passed in an hash as argument, as required by #section

  FeatureType.default_new(:name => "exon")

GTRubyConfigurator: added "upload" functionality

with "upload" is meant the action to set the corresponding
gt config object to the values kept in an instance of the
class including this module

- each attribute has now an #upload_<attr> method
- the whole instance gets and #upload method, which
  uploads all configuration attributes
- an additional method #upload_except(*attributes) allows
  to easily upload all attributes except the given ones,
  if it is necessary to avoid circular references

GT Server: code divided and partially rewritten

code divided in
* script/gt_server => only the init script
* script/gt_server.lib => directory with the other files
  * server.rb => class GTServerClass, initialize and test_call methods
  * parsing.rb => module Parsing, feature_index, feature_types, seqids...
  * configuration.rb => module Configuration, config objects cache ...
  * output.rb => module Output, image, image_map ...

cache for feature index now (when appropriate) considers if the add_introns
option was on or off

each cache, i.e. feature_index (on/off), feature types, config objects,
image and image map, has a separate mutex object, which is not called
on the whole method but always "atomic" on the statement that uses
the cache; the private "lock" method makes the mutex synchronize call
easier

the private "log" method allows to log on the STDOUT (default),
to turn off the logging (initialize with .new(nil)) or to log to
file (create the file object and pass it as argument to new()); it
incorporates the need to flush the buffer

src_clean

new way to start a db from scratch

- rake db:migrate is not a good way, as migrations are
  not intendet for the creation of the DB from scratch
  according to the RAILS API
- the db/schema_info.rb file is the authorative source
  for the creation of the DB
- as we want to load also some default data, I saved
  these under db/default_data in yaml format
- rake db:schema:load is the default rails task to
  create a DB from scratch
- I created some other tasks to simplify the process
  under lib/tasks/db:rake
- rake db:default_data:load now loads into the newly
  created database the default data from the yaml files
- the example user creation was left separate as it may
  not be required, e.g. in produciton environment
- the task db:example_user:load create the example
  user and uploads for him any gff3 files under test/gff3
- the task db:load runs the schema loading and default data loading
- the task db:load_with_foo makes the same plus creates user "foo"
- the user loading will work only if a gt_server is running
- documentation in README updated
- I deleted schema_extra.rb, that was my previous idea
  how to implement this, but not very intuitive
  and correct

  and in a <h1> tag at the beginning of the page
- this ensures that each page has a meaningful <title>
- an helper method for the <title> tag was written,
  which adds "GenomeViewer" if the string is not already
  in @title, and in addition concatenates the content of @subtitle
  if this is present
- a common place for messages (flash[:info], green and
  flash[:errors], red) was found, just after the initial h1

changed login and logout behaviour

- login works now as follows:
  - homepage / register / recover_password => redirect to file_manager (own files)
  - public files / browse a public file => stay on the page

- logout works now as follows:
  - configuration / upload page / file manager => redirect to homepage
  - public files / browse a public file (also own) => stay on the page
  - browse a private file => redirect to hp + show a message

changed behaviour on not authorized access

* NOT AUTHORIZED replaced by a more user friendly message
 and redirecting to the homepage

true condition was defined as different from 'f' and 0 in order to
comply with different definitions of the boolean column in different
databases (e.g. mysql => 0 and sqlite => 'f')
modified layout to include prototype and active_scaffold

added a column to "users" to cache the public annotations count

The column "public_annotations_count" was added to cache the number of public
annotations present in each record. This simplifies and speeds up the process
of selecting those users which have a public annotation for listing in the
public repository. On the other side it must be incremented/decremented each
time the status of an annotation is changed (see modification of file_manager.rb).

If this is the only application accessing the database, the column will
contain meaningful data. If other applications write in the database, they
must respect this cache column.

renamed directory app/controllers/config to app/controllers/config_modules

The directory contains modules loaded by in_session_controller.
The renaming avoids any interference with the namespace Config:: of
the active scaffold plugin.

Active Scaffold is a Rails plugin (under MIT license) that makes easy
to create a good paginated AJAX-based CRUD interface which can be customized
overriding the default parameters and views.

Homepage: http://activescaffold.com/

db/schema.rb added to the repository

* schema.rb represent the current state of the database
* according to rails apis schema.rb and *not* the migrations should
  be used to recreate the entire db e.g. by installing the application
  so by installing you should use rake:schema:load and not rake:migrate
* the schema is automatically dumped after each migration
  however, it does not dumps anything else than tables (e.g. views) and
  misses some features of migrations (e.g. data loading)
* to cope with this, a file schema_extra.rb containing the extra "undumped"
  code was created
* just add
    require 'db/schema_extra.rb'
  before the last "end" in schema.rb
* the latter step must be repeated if you use rake:migrate
  or rake:rollback as schema.rb is deleted and recreated from scratch

refactoring of non-standard variable and method names in gtserver

 - the standard of ruby is variable_name and not variableName
 - this is true for parameters, variables and methods
 - the whole code I wrote (hope) follows this standard
 - part of the code you wrote follows it
 - I think it should be nice to have a unified standard
   for the whole projekt and I don't see any possible reason
   not to adopt the universal standard of ruby code
 - therefore help me standardize the code
 - I renamed the whole variables and method names in gtserver
   and all their calls in other methods (used grep for it)

some adjustments to the last commit

 - the webpage for dominations config must still be rendered operative

changed db schema for dominations

 - with the old schema (a simple m:n table) was impossible to distinguish
   the case in which an user has an empty domination list for a feature
   and the case in which he wants the default domination list
 - now there is two tables
   - domination_configuration belongs to an user and defines the "dominator"
   - in the new table dominated_features there is zero, one or many references
     to the domination_configuration
 - so now:
   - if a user has a domination_configuration for a feature class that means
     that he ovverrided the default of view.lua
   - his domination_configuration for a feature class can be an empty list
     (which was impossible before this change)
   - if he has no domination_configuration for a feature class the one of
     view.lua is used

correction to last commit

(1) The file app/controllers/application.rb was not in the right version
(2) The commit msg should have been:

generation of png images fixed: a stream is sent directly to the browser

 - 1 - the SequenceRegion#to_png method now returns the png data
       and not a filename anymore. Please note that until the genometools
       will require to save the data in a file, this method will have
       to save the data in a tmp file (which is then delete) and then
       read the data again (that will be sent directly to the browser
       from the controller, see point 2). This, however, impacts the performance.

 - 2 - an action png_image was added to (for the moment) application.rb
       [Marvin, please move it later to your browser controller] and
       calls SequenceRegion#to_png with the right parameters (from the
       params hash), sending the png data directly to the browser

 - 3 - an example of application is app/views/in_session/view.html.erb

       image_tag(url_for(:action=>:png_image,
                         :annotation=>params[:annotation],
                         :sequence_region=>params[:sequence_region],
                         :seq_begin=>params[:seq_begin],
                         :seq_end=>params[:seq_end]))

       [the view was rewritten to use the new methods, although it will be
       replaced, as an example usage; now it correctly moves right and left
       and zooms, however it shows always the first sequence_region (see _navbar)

generation of png images fixed: a stream is sent directly to the browser

 - 1 - the SequenceRegion#to_png method now returns the png data
       and not a filename anymore. Please note that until the genometools
       will require to save the data in a file, this method will have
       to save the data in a tmp file (which is then deleted) and then
       read the data again (that will be sent directly to the browser
       from the controller, see point 2). This, however, impacts the performance.

 - 2 - an action png_image was added to (for the moment) application.rb
       [Marvin, please move it later to your browser controller] and
       calls SequenceRegion#to_png with the right parameters (from the
       params hash), sending the png data directly to the browser

 - 3 - an example of application is app/views/in_session/view.html.erb
       which was changed accordingly (but will be replaced by the browser
       controller of marvin)

 - 3 - an example of application is view.html.erb of in_session controller

       image_tag(url_for(:action=>:png_image,
                         :annotation=>params[:annotation],
                         :sequence_region=>params[:sequence_region],
                         :seq_begin=>params[:seq_begin],
                         :seq_end=>params[:seq_end]))

       [the view was rewritten to use the new methods, although it will be
       replaced, as an example usage; now it correctly moves right and left
       and zooms, however it shows always the first sequence_region (see _navbar)]

annotation model: gff_data saved to tmp file if name and user not yet set

 * before this commit the method gff3_data=() would raise an exception
   if no filename could be calculated because the attributes user and
   name were not set yet; this way no Annotation.create() could have
   been used as the the order of the elements of the hash was not always
   the right one (that means: gff3_data after name and user)

 * now if no filename can be calculated the data is saved under tmp/gff_data
   in a file with a random name; when the other attributes are set (name
   and user) the file is moved to the right location

 * in addition now changes of user for an Annotation object are handled correctly

gff3_data_storage method of annotation model made public

 * the method returns the filename where the gff3_data is stored
 * this method is necessary for the SequenceRegion model to use the gtruby bindings

 (a possible way to avoid this could be to move all code using gtruby bindings
  to the annotation model and refer to it from the sequenceregion model?)

added some unit tests for annotation model

 * some sample annotations have been created directly in the
   unit test file (test/unit/annotation_test.rb) as fixtures
   have problems with the filesystem storage of gff3 data

 * some unit tests for the storage mechanism were added

specified a different path for the uploads in different environments

 * the global variable $GFF3_STORAGE_PATH sets the path where the gff3
   files are saved by the Annotation model

 * the value of this variable is set in the config files for the
   different environments under config/environments

 * uploads in the test environment will now load under test/uploads
   and not interfere with the "real" uploads under uploads

 * uploads in the development and production environment will for the
   moment be both under uploads

 * added the directory test/uploads to .gitignore

added some test gff3 data under test/gff3

 * these files are needed to create some unit tests
   for the annotation model

 Note: these files are actually test files copied from the genometools
 (should they stay here or should we refer to the genometools copies?)

fixed bugs in in_session_controller

 - a ".read" was missing, so that by upload not the content of the file was saved
   but a object id

 - ".create" for the annotation model cannot be currently used as the order of the
  parameters in the hash is not predetermined and gff3_data=() can be potentially
  called before an user and filename are assigned; therefore substituted with ".new"

annotation models raises exceptions if data is saved before a filename can be set

 - to determine the path/filename you need an user and a filename being already set
 - if this is not the case and gff3_data=() is used this raises an exception

note: this does not allow to use annotation as an usual model (for example .create() method
is dangerous because the gff3_data=() can be called before other methods)

two way to fix this are: redefine create() or save the data in a temporary location if
no filename can be yet calculated and move it to the right location after .user=() and .name=()
methods are called

Added general project rules under doc/project_rules

 - The content is copy-pasted from the email of Gordon Gremme

annotations are now parsed through gtruby bindings to find sequence regions

 in Annotation model

 - added method get_sequence_regions_params that uses the gt bindings
 - the method is called by the create_sequence_regions (after_save callback)

filesystem storage of gff3 data totally encapsulated in Annotation model

 uploads/users directory renamed in uploads/private
 (uploads/public exists already)

 User model:

   - deleted all code to create / delete the uploads directory

 Annotation model:

   - now calculates automatically a filename and keeps it uptodate
   - creates and deletes uploads directories when needed
   - $GFF3_STORAGE_PATH in environment.rb defines the basis path
   - see also documentation of the class

notes: this way changing the filesystem storage to a memory- or
db-storage of the annotation will not require any change in the
code outside the Annotation class and db-table!
[completion of last commit]: a "{" too much was removed

Added a higher/better abstraction level to the storage of gff3 data

in the Annotation model:

 - added a method gff3_data=() to save the actual data (currently in a file). In this way the storage of gff3 data in filesystem, database, memory or whatever else in an internal matter of the annotation model and  who uses the class (e.g. controller) does not need to know about it.

   -- So now you can do: Annotation.create(
				:gff3_data=>"#gff3 data in a variable or file",
				:gff3_data_storage =>"#currently the filename where to save it"
				...

 - reverted the splitting of the column datasource (of last commit) into path and filename, as in Ruby is actually very easy to derive a filename or path with methods of the class File, so two separated fields are not necessary; the idea of "datasource" was to have an abstract column whose meaning can change according to the chosen storage method of gff3 data.

   -- So now datasource is back, but is called "gff3_data_storage".

created infrastructure for destroying annotations and users

 * User

   - deletion of an user cascades on his annotations

 * Annotation

   - deletion of an annotation cascades on its sequence regions
   - higher level of astraction introduced regarding the storage

      - introduced virtual attributes name, gff3_data_location (which
        replaces the real column datasource) and gff3_data
      - datasource column divided in filename and path in the
        current implementation
added link to source code repository in main page navbar

changed extension of all view files to html.erb

 - html.erb reflects the rails 2.0 standard
 - also changed application helper to look for _navbar.html.erb
added a project todo list under /doc

created first unit tests for model User

 - moved uploads dir generation in model code for self-contained user creation process
 - created fixtures and invalid parameters for users
 - created simple unit tests for user (validation tests)

 - minor unrelated change: fixed environments/development.rb for rails 2
   (ref to breakpointer elimintated)
  [as the files in config/environments were defaults, it would be good
   to copy there the defaults configs for rails 2.0]

frozen gems of rails 2.0.1 using rake:freeze:gems

preparation for upgrading to rails 2.0

* added a rake task to check for deprecation in the code
* changed all deprecated code in the views
* the code should be now ready for upgrade to rails 2

a first version creating an image dinamically (still just a test version)

* the m1.png visualized in the previous versions is now replaced by an image generated using
the genometools ruby bindings (gt_ruby)

* the generation of the image is done in the method SequenceRegion#to_png

* the image is saved in a temporary location - which is currently under /public, which is
a security issue

* the method SequenceRegion#to_png generates the image and returns the location of the file

* the view app/views/in_session/view.rhtml uses the .to_png method to show the generated image

* no validation was done at the moment

* the image is currently saved always under the same filename (this is still just a test version)
minor bug fix: login now possible with emails longer than 16 chars

renamed models: annotation_data -> annotation; annotation -> sequence_region

* minor: converted developer doc to plain text format
* deleted sql directory under db (obsolete)
The password is now stored as hash in the database
Replaced login by email address

Modified db schema, added an interface to the genometools

 modified db schema:
 * added a table for annotation_data
 * added a table for annotations
 * added an irregular plural annotation_data => annotation_data

 added an interface to the genometools:
 * if user uploads a file an AnnotationData object is instanciated
 * by saving the instance this event-chain is followed:
   * validation of the file content (needs to be wrapped to gt)
   * save row in database table annotation_data with the following info:
     * datasource (filename under current implementation)
     * user the file belongs_to
     * free text description of the file content
     * the public bool is left to the default false value
   * creation of an Annotation object for each sequence in the file

Improved the registration form and added validation of registration data

 - registration controller simplified; there is still only one action with a template ("register")
 - if register is successful it redirects to the login page
 - if register fails, it redirects again to the register page, giving explanations
 - the template uses form_errors.css to highlight errors (div added automatically by rails)
 - validation performed in the User model, upon call of the save method

Added a developer documentation, a layouting system and a session data eraser deamon

 * A new layouting system has been introduced to easily create pages using a derivate of the
   genometools sylesheet (it is documented in /doc/developer_documentation.rtf)
   Hereby @sidebar has been renamed to @navbar
 * An eraser deamon script has been written that deletes session data older than 24 hours.

updated register controller views further to use standard layout

added a common @page_title and @sidemenu through a private initialize method
in the controller
updated login controller to use the standard layout
updated register controller to use the standard layout

Added a meaningful index page for the default controller.

(note that it's still a preliminary version, that also deep-links some
pages on www.genometools.org)

Deleted folder "/database" that was containing the mysql database data

  The database data should not be included in the repository.
  The user that installs genomeviewer should be instructed to create a own database
  using his favourite DBMS program, use rake db:migrate to create the appropriate
  tables and edit the config/database.yml with the own paramaters.

Added a sidemenu system / Updated default/index to use standard layout and moved links in sidemenu In the standard layout there is now:
<%=@sidemenu%>
. This means that: - case 1: no @sidemenu variable is set: no sidemenu will be displayed (only an empty column on the side) - case 2: @sidemenu set: its contents are displayed to set the content of @sidemenu, one can use for example: @sidemenu = render_to_string :partial => "sidemenu" as done for the default controller, so that the content can be specified in a partial template

Added a base layout to be used by controllers when no other specific layout is indicated
(added as default layout in application.rb)
Standardized param / variables name according to rails/ruby conventions
Action names changed to use rails/ruby standards (all downcase, with underscores)
Made GenomeViewer using a derivate of the GenomeTools stylesheet
Addes missing files to the repository

Added a user account creation system

In order to get rid of referencial integrity problems the 1:user<->config:1
relation has been flattened.
Currently the users initial password is: m1

 to do:
 * send ua passwords via email
 * do more sophisticated cheking of the registration data
Added migrations code to the repository.
Made a modification to indulge in the concept of convention over configuration

Made the default route to controller 'default' functional

As long as an index.html file is contained in the public folder the default route is ignored.

Initial commit of a webservice for testing purposes

To get the webservice running carry out the following steps:
 * type the content of ./db/tables.sql in a mysql client
 * do a make libgtview=yes prefix=/path/to/repository/bin/ install
 * for every user in the DB create a folder in ./uploads/users

The current version provides:
 * session management (users can log in/out creation of new accounts is not possible)
 * file uploading (no file validation is currently done)
 * annotation viewing (service will fail proccessing simultanious requests from multiple users)
